<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GAMING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/sony-bungie-acquisition?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Sony goes Bungie jumping
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/sony-bungie-acquisition?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A screenshot from Destiny 2." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/b39707b5eff5211401d0713f1f25d8b8f4b46c7a-1920x1080.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Bungie</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">January was a full-out sprint for video game industry mergers, with major players jostling for a shot to have the best console money can’t buy due to supply issues. The latest: Sony announced plans to <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/31/sony-to-buy-video-game-maker-bungie-in-3point6-billion-deal.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">buy Bungie</a>, the studio responsible for the creation of both <em>Halo</em> and <em>Destiny</em>, for $3.6 billion.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The deal is not only notable for Bungie’s top-class IP offerings, but also for being another thrilling entry into the strange saga of the studio. Bungie was first acquired by Microsoft in 2000, becoming a household name and helping put Xbox on the map with <em>Halo</em>. After splitting from Microsoft in 2007, Bungie eventually entered a 10-year publishing deal with Activision Blizzard (which it left in 2019). Microsoft announced plans to buy Activision Blizzard earlier in January for a whopping $68.7 billion.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not to be forgotten in last month's gaming acquisition-athon, Take-Two Interactive agreed to purchase <em>Farmville</em> creator Zynga for $12.7 billion. Where’s Nintendo in all this? Stuck on the sand kingdom level of <em>Super Mario Odyssey</em> and screaming at each other.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">So what happens now?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Well, Xbox and PC <em>Destiny</em> fans can breathe a sigh of relief—according to Sony, the Bungie acquisition isn’t about creating new, exclusive content for Playstation (at least for now): Bungie will remain a multiplatform studio with the option to self-publish its games. Microsoft made a similar announcement for its Activision deal, confirming that it plans to continue supporting Activision Blizzard games on competing platforms (as it’s done with <em>Minecraft</em>).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While these cross-platform friendly moves could be seen as the dawning of a harmonious new era in the console wars, they more likely point to the industry’s increased focus on the subscription model.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Xbox Game Pass features over 400 games users can download and play for one monthly fee. Microsoft says the service has 25 million subscribers.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><em>Destiny 2</em></span><span>, Bungie’s most popular title, is free to play but offers season passes and expansions. The game has drawn in 20 million players since 2019.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In December, Bloomberg reported that Sony is planning a new subscription service to compete with Game Pass.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For now, subscription services and popular IP offer Sony and Microsoft a shield against the battered supply chain.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/31/the-nyt-buys-viral-sensation-wordle?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
It's the end of the Wordle as we know it
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/31/the-nyt-buys-viral-sensation-wordle?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A Wordle checkerboard " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/5af2bc1c6ef02ee74bff704aa672fff46db22ec0-734x486.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Wordle </em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And we feel…weird?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the second-biggest gaming deal of the day (but first in our hearts), the word puzzle sensation Wordle was <a href="https://www.nytco.com/press/wordle-new-york-times-games/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">acquired</a> by the New York Times.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The purchase is simultaneously a shock—considering how “grassroots” the Wordle experience felt—and also not that shocking at all. The NYT has been <a href="https://www.axios.com/new-york-times-games-puzzles-18c8c9aa-533c-4041-aecf-0910d20fcc46.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">vocal</a> about investing in its puzzles business, and now it adds this viral phenomenon to a heavyweight roster that already includes Crossword and Spelling Bee. The Times said it paid an amount in the low seven figures for Wordle.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Not a bad haul for a pandemic hobby. </strong>Created by software engineer Josh Wardle to help his puzzling-loving partner kill time during Covid, Wordle has exploded in recent months.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The game was played by just 90 people on Nov. 1, per the NYT. Fast forward to today, and it’s played by millions of people on the reg.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Wordle spawned numerous </span><span><a href="https://qntm.org/files/wordle/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">spinoffs</a></span><span>, has been </span><span><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/CZYqzSWNIYk/?utm_medium=copy_link" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">leveraged by brands</a></span><span> for marketing purposes, and was </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/aprilfiet/status/1485806788951908359?s=20&t=vJN7bOqG6klBKvEXlLMmsg" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">crocheted</a></span><span> into a pillow.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The only news that matters for Wordle fans: </strong>The game will remain initially free for new and existing players, the NYT said.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/beijing-winter-olympics-ambitious-covid-free-bubble?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Beijing wants the biggest bubble
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/beijing-winter-olympics-ambitious-covid-free-bubble?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Wukesong Sports Center Prepares For Beijing 2022" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/ce5c443f8a8596e7833c722fc5e01593b42dd936-4608x3072.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Beijing Youth Daily/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The 2022 Beijing Olympics must be taking notes from your mom after you broke curfew sophomore year. Ahead of the start of the games on Friday, China has created the most aggressive “<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/jan/28/keeping-the-olympics-covid-free-life-inside-beijings-closed-loop-bubble?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">closed loop</a>” Covid bubble of the pandemic.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s kinda like the NBA’s bubble in Orlando in 2020, but supersized. The Olympics bubble (which actually consists of three interconnected bubbles) will host about 11,000 international athletes, guests, and other participants, as well as thousands of Chinese volunteers and staff responsible for monitoring everyone’s movements within it.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Speaking of movement, people involved in the Olympics will be shuttled to three competition locations nearly 111 miles apart…all while avoiding contact with every single citizen in China’s second-largest city.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>All locations are connected by high-speed trains and bus routes used only by residents of the Olympic bubble. Chinese citizens have even been told not to help if they saw one of these bubble buses crash. </span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But even this bubble isn’t airtight.</strong> 46 Covid cases have been detected in the bubble, officials said yesterday.<em>—MM</em></p>
</div>

<tr>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/31/key-performance-indicators-february-1?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Key performance indicators
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>

<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/31/key-performance-indicators-february-1?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt='"The Complete Maus" graphic novel' style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/a841390dfa43b60af2b7667e46890538701ce828-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Maro Sironasian/AFP via Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat:</strong> <em>The Complete Maus</em>, the first and second installments of the Pulitzer Prize-winning graphic novel about the Holocaust, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/maus-tops-amazon-bestseller-list-after-tennessee-school-board-pulls-graphic-novel-11643650246?mod=hp_lead_pos11" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shot up</a> to the top of the Amazon bestseller list yesterday morning. Interest in <em>Maus </em>has soared since a Tennessee school board banned the book from its curriculum.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“I’ve done a lot of work on this and 5k is not enough.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">19-year-old Jack Sweeney, who runs a Twitter account that tracks Elon Musk’s private jet, told Insider why he <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-private-jet-tracking-twitter-account-2022-1?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">turned down</a> Musk’s offer of $5,000 to shut down the account. Musk has said that accounts that followed his movements were “becoming a security issue,” but Sweeney isn’t moved—he wants $50k from the tech mogul.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>The moral calculations of a billionaire. (<a href="https://wapo.st/3KU2GLg?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Washington Post</a>)</p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CRYPTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/31/crypto-exchange-ftx-raises-fresh-funds-at-a-usd32-billion-valuation?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Meet the next crypto giant
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Cryptocurrency exchange FTX is now <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/31/crypto-exchange-ftx-valued-at-32-billion-amid-bitcoin-price-plunge.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">valued at $32 billion</a> after its latest funding round, putting the three-year-old company in the ranks of the richest private startups in the world. It was worth just $1.2 billion in 2020.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here’s a quick cheat sheet to get you up to speed.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What does it offer? </strong>FTX calls itself a crypto exchange “built by traders, for traders.” It’s where you can buy or sell derivatives like crypto futures, options, leveraged tokens, and more. It’s not available in the US, but it has an affiliate that is: FTX U.S., which is worth $8 billion on its own.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why does it seem familiar? </strong>Probably because FTX has been on a marketing blitz, buying the naming rights to the Miami Heat’s arena and partnering with celebs like Tom Brady and Gisele Bündchen. It’ll also have a commercial spot in the upcoming Super Bowl.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Who’s in charge? </strong>Sam Bankman-Fried, FTX’s CEO, is a name to know. He lives in the Bahamas, wears T-shirts and shorts, is 29 years old, and has a net worth of more than $22 billion.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Crypto prices have taken a big tumble in recent months, and the biggest digital token—bitcoin—is down ~43% from its November peak. Bankman-Fried and his legions of investors think this is a temporary stumble in the sector’s upward march.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/sony-bungie-acquisition?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nSony goes Bungie jumping\n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/sony-bungie-acquisition?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A screenshot from Destiny 2.\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/b39707b5eff5211401d0713f1f25d8b8f4b46c7a-1920x1080.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eBungie\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJanuary was a full-out sprint for video game industry mergers, with major players jostling for a shot to have the best console money can’t buy due to supply issues. The latest: Sony announced plans to \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/31/sony-to-buy-video-game-maker-bungie-in-3point6-billion-deal.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebuy Bungie\u003c/a\u003e, the studio responsible for the creation of both \u003cem\u003eHalo\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eDestiny\u003c/em\u003e, for $3.6 billion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe deal is not only notable for Bungie’s top-class IP offerings, but also for being another thrilling entry into the strange saga of the studio. Bungie was first acquired by Microsoft in 2000, becoming a household name and helping put Xbox on the map with \u003cem\u003eHalo\u003c/em\u003e. After splitting from Microsoft in 2007, Bungie eventually entered a 10-year publishing deal with Activision Blizzard (which it left in 2019). Microsoft announced plans to buy Activision Blizzard earlier in January for a whopping $68.7 billion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNot to be forgotten in last month's gaming acquisition-athon, Take-Two Interactive agreed to purchase \u003cem\u003eFarmville\u003c/em\u003e creator Zynga for $12.7 billion. Where’s Nintendo in all this? Stuck on the sand kingdom level of \u003cem\u003eSuper Mario Odyssey\u003c/em\u003e and screaming at each other.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSo what happens now?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWell, Xbox and PC \u003cem\u003eDestiny\u003c/em\u003e fans can breathe a sigh of relief—according to Sony, the Bungie acquisition isn’t about creating new, exclusive content for Playstation (at least for now): Bungie will remain a multiplatform studio with the option to self-publish its games. Microsoft made a similar announcement for its Activision deal, confirming that it plans to continue supporting Activision Blizzard games on competing platforms (as it’s done with \u003cem\u003eMinecraft\u003c/em\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile these cross-platform friendly moves could be seen as the dawning of a harmonious new era in the console wars, they more likely point to the industry’s increased focus on the subscription model.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Xbox Game Pass features over 400 games users can download and play for one monthly fee. Microsoft says the service has 25 million subscribers.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eDestiny 2\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, Bungie’s most popular title, is free to play but offers season passes and expansions. The game has drawn in 20 million players since 2019.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn December, Bloomberg reported that Sony is planning a new subscription service to compete with Game Pass.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor now, subscription services and popular IP offer Sony and Microsoft a shield against the battered supply chain.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the second-biggest gaming deal of the day (but first in our hearts), the word puzzle sensation Wordle was \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytco.com/press/wordle-new-york-times-games/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eacquired\u003c/a\u003e by the New York Times.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe purchase is simultaneously a shock—considering how “grassroots” the Wordle experience felt—and also not that shocking at all. The NYT has been \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/new-york-times-games-puzzles-18c8c9aa-533c-4041-aecf-0910d20fcc46.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003evocal\u003c/a\u003e about investing in its puzzles business, and now it adds this viral phenomenon to a heavyweight roster that already includes Crossword and Spelling Bee. The Times said it paid an amount in the low seven figures for Wordle.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNot a bad haul for a pandemic hobby. \u003c/strong\u003eCreated by software engineer Josh Wardle to help his puzzling-loving partner kill time during Covid, Wordle has exploded in recent months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe game was played by just 90 people on Nov. 1, per the NYT. Fast forward to today, and it’s played by millions of people on the reg.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eWordle spawned numerous \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://qntm.org/files/wordle/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003espinoffs\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, has been \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CZYqzSWNIYk/?utm_medium=copy_link\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eleveraged by brands\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e for marketing purposes, and was \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/aprilfiet/status/1485806788951908359?s=20\u0026t=vJN7bOqG6klBKvEXlLMmsg\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecrocheted\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e into a pillow.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe only news that matters for Wordle fans: \u003c/strong\u003eThe game will remain initially Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe 2022 Beijing Olympics must be taking notes from your mom after you broke curfew sophomore year. Ahead of the start of the games on Friday, China has created the most aggressive “\u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/jan/28/keeping-the-olympics-covid-free-life-inside-beijings-closed-loop-bubble?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eclosed loop\u003c/a\u003e” Covid bubble of the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s kinda like the NBA’s bubble in Orlando in 2020, but supersized. The Olympics bubble (which actually consists of three interconnected bubbles) will host about 11,000 international athletes, guests, and other participants, as well as thousands of Chinese volunteers and staff responsible for monitoring everyone’s movements within it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSpeaking of movement, people involved in the Olympics will be shuttled to three competition locations nearly 111 miles apart…all while avoiding contact with every single citizen in China’s second-largest city.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAll locations are connected by high-speed trains and bus routes used only by residents of the Olympic bubble. Chinese citizens have even been told not to help if they saw one of these bubble buses crash. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBut even this bubble isn’t airtight.\u003c/strong\u003e 46 Covid cases have been detected in the bubble, officials said yesterday.\u003cem\u003e—MM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" in the ranks of the richest private startups in the world. It was worth just $1.2 billion in 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHere’s a quick cheat sheet to get you up to speed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat does it offer? \u003c/strong\u003eFTX calls itself a crypto exchange “built by traders, for traders.” It’s where you can buy or sell derivatives like crypto futures, options, leveraged tokens, and more.
